sub_topic: Lorentz transformation of coordinates and time
message_1: A spaceship is travelling at a velocity of 0.8c relative to an observer on Earth. At a certain point in time, the observer measures the time to be t = 10 seconds on their clock. What is the time reading on the spaceship's clock at the same moment, according to the observer? Use Lorentz transformation equations to solve the problem.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the time dilation formula from the Lorentz transformation equations. The time dilation formula is given by:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where t' is the time measured on the spaceship's clock, t is the time measured on the observer's clock, v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the given values, we have:

t' = 10 / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)

t' = 10 / sqrt(1 - 0.64)

t' = 10 / sqrt(0.36)

t' = 10 / 0.6

t' â‰ˆ 16.67 seconds

So, according to the observer, the time reading on the spaceship's clock at the same moment is approximately 16.67 seconds.
